question: Thirty minutes late. Think she'll show? She didn't last week. She was having a guava facial.
answer: Good morning, gentlemen. Welcome to another season of Indians' baseball. I know that it may not seem the same without Donald here this year, but I promise you by the end of the season this team will have made history. Unfortunately there are some in the press who feel that... "the ex-showgirl wife of Donald Phelps has no business being the owner of a major league baseball team." Obviously, Donald didn't feel that way or he wouldn't have left the team to me. And I was more than showgirl. I was a dancer. Now, I know some of you have doubts about my ability to run this franchise. God help you if I ever find out about it. Spring training begins in two weeks. Here's the list of people we'll be inviting to camp this year. I could sit here and tell you what a great year we're gonna have, but the facts are we lost the two best players we had to free agency. We haven't won a pennant in 30 years. We haven't even finished in the first division for 15. Obviously it's time to make some changes. What do ya think?

question: Most of these guys never had a prime.
answer: Cross him off then. It's time to shake things up, Charlie. Clear the board and start over.

question: Well, it's not the best material I've ever had to work with, but I'll do my best to see we move up a notch this year.
answer: I know you will, Charlie. That's why I'm movin' you up to General Manager. Congratulations. Well, that should do it for today. Thank you, gentlemen. Let's get to work.

question: Come on in, Charlie. Have a seat.
answer: I'm glad you called me in. I'm still unclear on a couple things

question: Oh, really? Like what?
answer: Well, if I'm the G.M., who's gonna be the Manager?

question: I was thinking of Lou Brown.
answer: Lou Brown?

question: He's managed the Toledo Mud Hens of the International League for the last 30 years. I think he'll fit right in with our team concept.
answer: What exactly is our team concept?

question: That's what I wanted to talk to you about. I want to put together a team that will help us relocate to Miami.
answer: What do you mean? Some of these guys are furniture movers?

question: I'm serious about this, Charlie. It's no secret I've never liked Cleveland much. The weather's lousy, downtown is a pit, the stadium's falling apart, and we can't draw dick. Another couple of years of this and I'm gonna have to start feeding Cha-Cha dog food.
answer: Mrs. Phelps, you can't just up and move a team on a whim...

question: It's hardly a whim. Miami's offered to build us a new stadium -- 62,000 capacity, 45 V.I.P. boxes, and no rent for the first million at the gate. Plus a 12 million dollar media guarantee; 45 percent of the concession gross, all of the parking and they pick up the stadium operations costs. No other franchise in baseball can match that deal.
answer: Even so, the League'll never let us leave Cleveland. We got a lease with the city.

question: The lease says we have the right to move if our attendance falls below 800,000 for the year. Paragraph 40, line 17. If we play bad enough, we should be able to come in under that.
answer: What are you saying? You want us to lose?

question: No, we've been losing. What I want us to do is finish dead last.
answer: Mister Phelps would never have approved of this.

question: Yeh.
answer: Hello, Jake? This is Charlie Donovan, new G.M. of the Cleveland Indians.

question: Yeh...
answer: I wanted to call and say the organization remembers you fondly from the years you played here and we'd love to have you come to spring training for a shot at this year's club.

question: Who is this?
answer: What?

question: Tire World.
answer: Lou? This is Charlie Donovan, the new G.M. of the Cleveland Indians. Listen, Lou, I hope you're sittin' down 'cause I got an offer you probably been dreamin' about your whole life. We been watchin' your progress down there at Toledo with a lotta interest and well... How would you like to manage the Indians this year?

question: I don't know...
answer: What do ya mean you don't know? This is a chance to manage in the big leagues.

question: Lemme think it over, will ya, Charlie. I got a guy on the other line about some whitewalls. I'll talk to ya later.
answer: Rick, we heard about your pitching out at Portland last year...

question: Rick, we heard about your pitching out at Portland last year...
answer: I'm, ah, not with them anymore...

question: We'd still like to take a look at ya at our spring camp in Arizona, March first.
answer: Yeh, well, I'm not sure I can make it by then.

question: Don't worry, we're gettin' you out on a sort of work furlough deal. Any questions?
answer: Yeh. Where's Cleveland?

question: Look, Lou, you been in baseball thirty years. Don't you wanna advance some?
answer: I used to coach the unwed mothers' softball team. I have advanced some.

question: Well, what are you really worried about? The money?
answer: Naw, I'm just not sure I'd be happy in a big organization like that. Owners are always on your back, tryin' to "help you out."

question: I don't think that's gonna be a problem.
answer: Down here baseball's a game, not a business. I don't wanta be a babysitter for a buncha millionaires who think they know it all already.

question: We don't have any millionaires.
answer: Well then, bonus babies or whatever you got...

question: Don't have any bonus babies either.
answer: Don't you have any proven major league talent?

question: Not that I know of.
answer: Well, then... I'll be up in a couple days.

question: What?
answer: Sounds like my kinda team. Have my contracts ready.

question: Guess I really put the screws to him.
answer: returning to the dugout at the end of the inning, wondering what the hell he's doin' here. Hello.

question: Jake, Charlie Donovan again.
answer: Oh yeh, Charlie, look, I'm sorry about this morning...

question: No problem. Look, Jake, camp starts on the first. Can you make it?
answer: Sure.

question: You been stayin' in shape down there?
answer: Oh hell, yeh, I work out every day.

question: I thought so. See ya in Arizona.
answer: approaching his MANAGER. Luis, I'm not gonna be playin' anymore. I got a tryout in the States. But I changed at the motel. coming out of the stadium, his bats and gloves over his shoulder. He has on his spikes and a pair of boxer shorts.

question: Who's that?
answer: I think it's Cerrano. Defected from Cuba. Wanted religious freedom.

question: What's his religion?
answer: Voodoo.

question: Thought you didn't have any high- priced talent.
answer: I forgot about Dorn, 'cause he's only high-priced. Got him as a free agent three years ago.

question: Still hits the ball pretty well, doesn't he?
answer: Yeh, he just can't field it.

question: We'll shape him up.
answer: Don't recognize this guy.

question: How the knees holdin' up, Jake?
answer: Great. Never been better.

question: Mobility's good? No problem gettin' off the throw to second?
answer: No problem.

question: I need a catcher, Jake. Somebody who can keep this team together on the field. You were a helluva player when you were sound, but around the league they think you can't take the pounding anymore.
answer: Around the league they're wrong.

question: I'm gonna have to put you to the test, ya know. So, I want the absolute truth here. Are you 100 percent?
answer: Yeh. Would I bullshit about somethin' like that?

question: How much? Better teach him some control before he kills somebody. C'mon, Dorn, get in front of the damn ball. Don't give me this ole' bullshit.
answer: I took one of these in the eye last year. Nearly lost my sight.

question: I'm deeply moved. Every time you play it off your hip, you give me forty sit-ups.
answer: What! That's Little League shit.

question: What are you gonna have?
answer: I don't know. What language is this?

question: French.
answer: They got patty melts over there?

question: Hello. Jake? How did you know I was here?
answer: Just a hunch. I took you there when you got your masters. I figure you're probably wearing the black velvet dress with the red sash.

question: How did you know that? I didn't have this dress when we were...
answer: You look great.

question: Thanks. What are you doin' here? Aren't you supposed to be in Mexico somewhere?
answer: I'm playin' with the Indians again. Back in the Bigs.

question: That's great. I'm happy for you, Jake. I gotta get back...
answer: Wait a minute. What's your number. I tried calling you at home, but you're not listed...

question: My life is different from when you knew me.
answer: Meaning what? That I don't know you anymore?

question: Couldn't we talk about this some other time? I really gotta...
answer: Okay, just gimme your number.

question: I don't think that's a good idea.
answer: Why not? Because of the guy you're with? What is he, a banker?

question: Lawyer. Please, Jake, he's watching us.
answer: I'm not leavin' without your number. You still wear those great little tortoise-shell glasses? I always loved it when you took them off.

question: Jake...
answer: The number, Lynn...

question: All right. 555-9314.
answer: Thank you. I'm back, Lynn, and I'm gonna be around.

question: Bottom of the first, Willie Mays Hayes to lead it off for the tribe.
answer: going through his warmup routine at the plate.

question: A lotta people say you can tell how a season's gonna go by the first hitter of the year. In the last fifteen years, the Indians have never had the season lead-off hitter reach base. Hot shot toward the hole. Rudia knocks it down, gets up, fires to first. Too late! Hayes beats it! And so the string is broken. Maybe things will turn around a little for the Indians this year.
answer: I plan to get at least a double out of it.

question: And now Hayes is putting on a pair of black gloves, sending a little message to the Yankees.
answer: Bought a hundred of these, one for each base I plan to steal. Excuse me, here, I gotta take my first step toward the Hall of Fame.

question: Looked like a strike anyway. You want me to go get him?
answer: No, let's see how he reacts. Interesting.

question: At least he hit what he was aimin' at.
answer: I think you can go get him now.

question: God, I was horse shit tonight.
answer: Only thing you got to be sorry about was hittin' Coleman.

question: What?
answer: If you wanted to send a message, it shoulda been to Haywood. He hit the damn homer. Coleman was just picking his nose in the on-deck circle. Forget the other stuff. It coulda happened to anybody. Besides, Haywood didn't hit it that good. That ball wouldn't have been out of a lotta parks.

question: Oh yeh, name one.
answer: Yellowstone.

question: Jake, you shouldn't have come here.
answer: I was wonderin' why you'd give an old friend a bum phone number.

question: Let's talk in my office, okay?
answer: I don't wanna talk in your office.

question: I told you I don't think it's a good idea for us to see each other.
answer: Why not?

question: We don't have anything in common. Sometimes I wonder if we ever did.
answer: What are you talkin' about? We were both athletes, world class, hot for each other. What more can you have in common?

question: I stopped bein' an athlete three years ago. Books are my life now. Don't you dare laugh, Jake. In two years I've put together one of the best special collections departments in the country.
answer: So what is it? You're still sore I never read Moby Dick?

question: You never read anything I asked you to.
answer: Not like what's-his-name at the restaurant?

question: His name is Tom, and keep your voice down.
answer: What do ya see in this guy?

question: He's stable. He's intelligent... and I've never found him in bed with a stewardess.
answer: That's 'cause no stewardess would have him. Wouldn't you rather be with somebody who's in demand?

question: Just like always, you don't take anything seriously. Everything's a joke to you.
answer: C'mon, Lynn, for Christ sake, I'm just tryin' to loosen things up a little. I'm gettin' frostbite here.

question: Tom and I are getting married in the fall.
answer: What? That's crazy, Lynn. I got plans for us.

question: What plans?
answer: I was gonna play another a year or two, then we go to Hawaii, and have a couple kids who grow up to be Olympic champions.

question: How can you think stuff like that? I haven't seen you in two years. You never even wrote me a letter.
answer: I'm sorry, Lynn, but I wasn't exactly proud of my situation. C'mon, you didn't think about me at all since I been gone?

question: Not so loud, Jake.
answer: Remember the three nights we spent on the beach in Vera Cruz? You have nights like that with Mr. Briefcase?

question: What about the night you had in Detroit with Miss Dairy Queen?
answer: What was I supposed to do? She bet me fifty bucks she had a better body than you. I had to defend your honor.

question: What a bunch of bullshit! I have a much better body than she does.
answer: She's right. Take it from me, she really does. I mean Miss Dairy Queen has quantity, I give her that, but the, ah, quality just isn't there. How many think Lynn oughta give me another shot? The ayes have it.

question: You haven't changed at all, have you?
answer: I'm afraid I have or I wouldn't be here. C'mon, Lynn, I don't wanna do time for things that happened years ago.

question: I'm sorry, Jake. You'll always be the little boy who wouldn't grow up.
answer: Lynn, wait...

question: A quarter of the season's gone, we're 15 and 24, seven games out of first. Our attendance is just below 180,000. That's bad, but not bad enough.
answer: Projected over the whole season, we stand to wind up 36 games under .500 and 28 out of first. That should be bad enough for anybody.

question: We finished 24 out last year and still drew 890,000. When school's out for the summer, attendance is liable to rise. Plus, this team is showing signs of improvement. I didn't think we'd win 15 games all year. Any ideas?
answer: On how we can get worse? How about a series of fines for good play? Maybe a $30,000 bonus to the guy chosen Least Valuable Player.

question: I'm about ready to turn in. I've anesthetized my knees enough.
answer: Ah... yeh... sure. My first autograph. I couldn't give these away a couple weeks ago. Thanks.

question: You're a celebrity now, Vaughn.
answer: I thought you had to do somethin' good to be a celebrity.

question: What'd I tell ya.
answer: Hi, Rodger. This is Vicki and Rene.

question: Hi, doll. This is Steve Harris.
answer: Where's your buddy Gant?

question: They cut him to make room for bristle boy over there.
answer: Is that Vaughn, the guy they call Wild Thing?

question: Yeh.
answer: He's kinda cute. They say he could be a big star.

question: What are you talkin' about? He couldn't find the plate if it was magnetized. He won't last the year.
answer: He struck out five in a row before the wild pitches. Maybe I'll check him out.

question: Wait a minute, you're with me.
answer: I don't remember you makin' any date.

question: Since when do I have to make a date? Who's been showin' you this town the last three years?
answer: Ancient history, Rodger. I gotta look out for myself now. I don't have to be a slave to no .235 hitter. Wild Thing, you make my heart sing.

question: "Moby Dick?" What is that?
answer: It's one of the masterpieces of American literature, that's all.

question: Lynn put you on to this?
answer: Long time ago.

question: Well, we're goin' to a club tonight. You wanna come along?
answer: No, I got some more reading to do.

question: What, you got a test or somethin'? Why don't you just go over and see her? Maybe she'll let you slide on a couple of these.
answer: I might if I knew where she lives.

question: Easy. Tail her home from the library.
answer: You mean sit in a car and wait for her to come out? That's kinda juvenile, don't you think?

question: Yeh.
answer: pulling up outside the townhouse he saw Lynn go into. He goes up the stairs and knocks on the door. Look, Lynn, I'm sorry I followed you home but I wanna...

question: No, really, come on in for a drink. Excuse me, everybody, this is Jake Taylor. Jake, Arthur and Claire Holloway Brent and Janice Bowden. Jake is a professional baseball player. So, Jake, what brings you here this evening?
answer: I, ah, just had a couple books I wanted to discuss with Lynn. I thought this was her place.

question: Well, it soon will be.
answer: Yeh, I heard you guys were engaged. Congratulations.

question: Thank you. What can I get you to drink?
answer: Beer'll be fine. The Indians. Yeh, we have uniforms and everything. It's really great.

question: They're last right now, but hopefully moving up, eh, Jake?
answer: That depends on how good they are, I guess. I make the League minimum.

question: Alternate on the '80 Olympic Team. Well, I gotta be goin'. Nice to have met you all.
answer: Let me walk you out.

question: Thanks for the beer.
answer: Don't mention it.

question: I'll let you know if I land a good job. I know you're concerned about it.
answer: Yeh, well, I just wanted Lynn to know what she would've had ahead of her. Stay away from her.

question: C'mon in, Rick. Rick, I'm not gonna beat around the bush here. You got a great arm, one of the best I've ever seen, but your control hasn't come around like we hoped it would. Now, there are a lotta pitchers that started out wild and, after workin' it out in the minors, for a while, went on to great careers. Take Sandy Koufax there...
answer: What about Koufax?

question: Never mind Koufax. Read these letters, starting at the top. Can't read it, can you?
answer: You gonna send me to the minors?

question: Okay, let's get nasty here, Rick. You know he's lookin' for this pitch. Gotta come up with somethin' studly.
answer: Fuckin' Dorn. Game shoulda been over by now. Dorn coulda had that ball. He tanked it on purpose.

question: This isn't the California Penal League, Vaughn. We're professionals here. We don't tank a play for personal reasons, so cut the crybaby shit. You've pitched a helluva game. You wanna finish it, don't ya? Can you give me a strike on this pitch?
answer: Yeh, but I don't know if there'll be much on it. My arm feels like jello.

question: Just make sure it's over the plate. I want him to swing.
answer: The last time I did that, the guy hit one that hasn't landed yet.

question: Don't worry, I'll take care of it. By the way, I been meaning to ask you. Why'd you steal that car?
answer: I was bored.

question: She's at it again. I've had it with this nickel and dime stuff. I'm gonna get the Bitch on the phone.
answer: You wanted to see the Bitch?

question: Yeh.
answer: Don't you think you oughta cover yourself with a towel first, Mr. Brown?

question: There aren't any towels, and I'm too old to be diving under benches.
answer: Well, I can take it if you can.

question: What happened to the new whirlpool we were supposed to get?
answer: Revenue problems have forced us to cut back on equipment. We'll simply have to fix the old one.

question: You fixed it six times already. And now there's no hot water in the showers.
answer: The pipes in this building are old and rusted. We're replacing them, but it's a long, expensive process.

question: How am I supposed to keep my players healthy with cold water and no therapy equipment?
answer: Your players will just have to get a little tougher. What are they, a bunch of pansies?

question: Over 162 games even tough guys get sprains, sore arms, muscle pulls...
answer: It's only temporary. Besides, these guys weren't playing that good when the equipment was workin'. If I could get anybody to come and watch this team, none of this would be necessary. You oughta be grateful I can still pay your salaries.

question: Ah shit, here comes Lou. Gimme a break, Mel. I gotta get outta here. Right. Good idea.
answer: Hey, don't you go anywhere. I wanna have a few words with you. What are we arguin' about here?

question: Fucker called that a ball.
answer: You mean the one that was a foot outside?

question: Yeh.
answer: leaving her seat and starting up the aisle. in the parking lot. As she goes to unlock her car, Taylor looks around hurriedly for some kind of vehicle to follow her in.

question: You still got that great kick. Just like the first time I ever saw you.
answer: You follow me here too?

question: Yeh, what did you want to see me about?
answer: What do you mean?

question: You wouldn't have been at the game if you didn't want to see me about something.
answer: I just wanted to see you play.

question: How was I?
answer: You looked good, but you oughta open your stance a little. They're pitching you inside.

question: I'll try that. You wanna have some dinner?
answer: Sorry, I already ate.

question: Right. I forgot your life is different now.
answer: Thanks for the race.

question: Anytime. Whose place are we at this time?
answer: Mine. You follow me again?

question: Yeh. When I saw you at the game, I figured you wanted to see me about something.
answer: I just wanted to see you play.

question: How was I?
answer: You looked good, but you oughta open your stance a little. They're pitchin' you inside.

question: I'll try that.
answer: I think I oughta tell you that I'm moving in with Tom.

question: Goin' uptown, huh?
answer: I'm not goin' uptown, I just want to lead a regular life. You know, like an adult maybe. With a house and a garden and normal hours.

question: You think I can't lead a regular life?
answer: You like the life you've had, Jake. You like hangin' out with the boys, livin' in hotels, eatin' dinner at midnight, having girls send you their underwear in the mail. Remember the surprise party I threw for you when you made the All-Star team? You never showed up, but the doorbell rang once and we all got quiet and hid behind the furniture. It was a guy to serve you with a paternity suit.

question: That was a hoax. The girl was just trying to get some publicity.
answer: Yes, but you had obviously been with her. And it happened in front of all our friends.

question: I was drownin', Lynn. The endorsements were dryin' up, my knees were goin', they were talkin' about sendin' me down. I was just trying to hold on to somethin', prove to myself I was still an All-Star. I don't care about that anymore. I know I don't have much time left in baseball. I'm just a guy trying to put his life back together. Thinkin' about you was the only thing that kept me goin' in Mexico.
answer: I've come back to you too many times, Jake. I can't afford to believe you anymore.

question: I guess this is our last hurrah then.
answer: I guess so. Did you really read "Moby Dick?"

question: Cover to cover. When's the wedding?
answer: October third.

question: Your mom and dad like this guy?
answer: You're still their favorite.

question: Gonna be a big wedding?
answer: Tom doesn't like big weddings. You coulda read Plot Outlines of 101 Great Novels.

question: Where?
answer: At any library.

question: I mean the wedding.
answer: All Saints on Euclid.

question: Nice church.
answer: Yeh. Who saved Ishmael at the end?

question: Nobody. It was Queequeg's coffin. Am I invited?
answer: Where?

question: To the wedding.
answer: If you want. Maybe you really did read it. This doesn't change anything, you know. We were always good at this.

question: Lynn?
answer: What?

question: The zipper on your skirt is stuck.
answer: Use your imagination.

question: Well, my worst fears have been confirmed. We're 60 and 60, nine games out of first, and only two out of the first division. Who do those guys think they are?
answer: Maybe you just have to accept the fact that they're not as bad as you'd hoped.

question: I don't have to accept anything. Our attendance is only beginning to rise. If we can force a losing streak for a week or two, we can still turn this thing around. The fans are used to losers here. At the first sign of a slump they'll give up on this team.
answer: What's left to do? You've taken away everything you can.

question: Can I borrow one of those, man? They don't have any magazines on this bus.
answer: Sure, go ahead. I think my reading days are over.

question: Macbeth. This a good one?
answer: These are all Hall of Famers.

question: I'll trade you Song of Hiawatha for The Deerslayer.
answer: Naw, I'm not into Song of Hiawatha.

question: All right then, how about Crime and Punishment?
answer: Yeh, that sounds pretty good. That's a detective story, right?

question: Mind if I join you?
answer: Donovan. Hell no. What are you doin' here?

question: Just wanted to get out on the road. You damn near pulled one out today.
answer: Someday we'll figure out how to beat those guys.

question: Ya know, you've done a helluva job this year.
answer: Sixty and sixty-one is hardly a helluva job.

question: With this club it is.
answer: Ya know, when I first got to camp I figured this team had no chance. I was just hopin' we'd win enough that I could stay on and really start to build something here. But there's a lotta talent on this club, Charlie. The veterans are starting to play back to form and the rookies are developing faster than I thought. There's two or three potential all- stars in there. I think we're a first division team right now.

question: You really believe that, don't you?
answer: I know it. All we need is something to bring it all together.

question: Rachel Phelps would never allow that.
answer: What do you mean?

question: She doesn't want you in the first division. She doesn't even want you in Cleveland.
answer: I got somethin' I think you oughta know about. I wouldn't have known about it myself if Charlie Donovan hadn't told me, although I shoulda guessed it from everything that's happened. It seems that Mrs. Phelps doesn't think too highly of our worth. She put this team together because she thought we'd be bad enough to finish dead last, knockin' attendance down to the point where she could move the team to Miami. And get rid of all of us for better personnel.

question: We haven't won anything yet. We still got one more to go.
answer: Hey, Taylor, there's a coupla drop- dead Annies outside. One of 'em says she used to know you pretty good. Brunette, great rack...

question: Darla.
answer: Yeh. What doya say we chat 'em up?

question: I don't know...
answer: C'mon, you're not gonna keep moonin' over that library chick, are you? Forget her, she's gone.

question: You still got that black Corvette? The one that the sound system took up the whole trunk?
answer: No, I had to sell it.

question: I thought they gave them to ya.
answer: Not after your knees go bad.

question: That's all right, you'll be gettin' a new one now.
answer: Darla, I don't think I can do this.

question: What do you mean? We did this between innings once.
answer: I guess I'm just not that guy anymore.

question: You wanted to see me?
answer: Yeh, Rick. I just wanted to tell you that I'm startin' Harris tomorrow against the Yankees, even though it's your turn in the rotation. He's got more experience and a little better record against the Yankees.

question: Yeh, sure. Whatever's best for the team.
answer: Don't read anything into it, Rick. You're one of the guys that got us here.

question: Yeh, okay. I don't think I'd be very good company tonight.
answer: Why not?

question: Nothin'. Job problem. I'm, ah, a ball player.
answer: I know, but that's not why I came over. I don't chase ball players.

question: Why did you come over then?
answer: Because you're the sexiest man I've ever laid eyes on, and you look like you could use a... friend.

question: Where you goin'?
answer: I've gotta get home.

question: I didn't even get your name.
answer: Suzanne. Suzanne Dorn

question: Suzanne Dorn?
answer: Mrs. Suzanne Dorn. So long. You're a great kid. Hello, Jake.

question: You look beautiful.
answer: Thank you. I didn't think you'd come.

question: I can't stay. We gotta get to the park.
answer: Good luck today, Jake.

question: Yeh, you too. Tell me one thing. The night you came up to my hotel -- was there really a library conference?
answer: No, I came to see you.

question: Too bad it didn't work out better. I just wanna say I'm sorry for all the things I've put you through over the years.
answer: Even for last night?

question: Can't be sorry for that. Nothing happened.
answer: Then you weren't defending my honor again?

question: Come in. Hello, Lou, what can I do for ya?
answer: I wanted to hand in my resignation before you had a chance to fire me.

question: What do you mean?
answer: I know what you been tryin' to do with this team. After the season, I want no part of it.

question: Well, I knew I could count on Charlie to tell somebody. I was just afraid he might take too long.
answer: Why would you want him to tell somebody?

question: So you'd tell the team, hopefully getting them mad enough to knock themselves out trying to prove they belonged in this league. I think it worked.
answer: You tryin' to make me believe you wanted us to win all along? Bullshit. What about the plane, the bus, the bad hotels...

question: We were broke. We couldn't afford anything better. Donald left the team nearly bankrupt. If we'd had another losing season, I would have had to sell the team. I knew we couldn't win with the team we had, so I decided to bring in new players and see how they'd do with the proper motivation. There was never any offer from Miami. I made it all up.
answer: Why should I believe any of this? Now that we're winnin' it's easy for you to jump on the bandwagon.
